trans-unit.source: Restore a deleted Azure SQL database in Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Restore a deleted Azure SQL database in Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure SQL Database, restore deleted database, recover deleted database, Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure SQL Database, restore deleted database, recover deleted database, Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Restore a deleted Azure SQL database in Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Restore a deleted Azure SQL database in Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to restore a deleted Azure SQL database in <link><linkText>Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to restore a deleted Azure SQL database in <link><linkText>Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You can restore a database that was deleted during its retention period to the point at which it was deleted.
trans-unit.target: You can restore a database that was deleted during its retention period to the point at which it was deleted.

trans-unit.source: The retention period is determined by the service tier of the database.
trans-unit.target: The retention period is determined by the service tier of the database.

trans-unit.source: Restoring a deleted Azure SQL database creates a new database.
trans-unit.target: Restoring a deleted Azure SQL database creates a new database.

trans-unit.source: The service automatically selects the service tier based on the backup used at the restore point.
trans-unit.target: The service automatically selects the service tier based on the backup used at the restore point.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you have available quota on the logical server to create another database.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you have available quota on the logical server to create another database.

trans-unit.source: If you'd like to request an increased quota, contact <link><linkText>Azure Support</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you'd like to request an increased quota, contact <link><linkText>Azure Support</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Restrictions and Security
trans-unit.target: Restrictions and Security

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Restore a deleted Azure SQL database in the Azure portal</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Restore a deleted Azure SQL database in the Azure portal</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: How to: Restore a deleted Azure SQL database in Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: How to: Restore a deleted Azure SQL database in Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: You must use certificate based authentication to run the following cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: You must use certificate based authentication to run the following cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the Use the certificate method section in How to install and configure Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the Use the certificate method section in How to install and configure Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Get the list of recoverable databases by using the <link><linkText>Get-AzureSqlDatabase</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Get the list of recoverable databases by using the <link><linkText>Get-AzureSqlDatabase</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Use the RestorableDropped switch and specify the ServerName of the server from which the database was deleted.
trans-unit.target: Use the RestorableDropped switch and specify the ServerName of the server from which the database was deleted.

trans-unit.source: Running the following command stores the results in a variable called $RecoverableDBs.
trans-unit.target: Running the following command stores the results in a variable called $RecoverableDBs.

trans-unit.source: PS C:\>$RecoverableDBs = Get-AzureSqlDatabase -ServerName "myserver" –RestorableDropped
trans-unit.target: PS C:\>$RecoverableDBs = Get-AzureSqlDatabase -ServerName "myserver" –RestorableDropped

trans-unit.source: Choose the deleted database you want to restore from the list of deleted databases.
trans-unit.target: Choose the deleted database you want to restore from the list of deleted databases.

trans-unit.source: Type the deleted database number from the $RecoverableDBs list.
trans-unit.target: Type the deleted database number from the $RecoverableDBs list.

trans-unit.source: PS C:\>$Database = $RecoverableDBs[]
trans-unit.target: PS C:\>$Database = $RecoverableDBs[]

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to get a restorable dropped database object, see <link><linkText>Get-AzureSqlDatabase</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to get a restorable dropped database object, see <link><linkText>Get-AzureSqlDatabase</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Begin the restore by using the <link><linkText>Start-AzureSqlDatabaseRestore</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Begin the restore by using the <link><linkText>Start-AzureSqlDatabaseRestore</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Specify the following parameters:
trans-unit.target: Specify the following parameters:

trans-unit.source: SourceRestorableDroppedDatabase
trans-unit.target: SourceRestorableDroppedDatabase

trans-unit.source: TargetDatabaseName of the database you are restoring to.
trans-unit.target: TargetDatabaseName of the database you are restoring to.

trans-unit.source: Store what is returned to a variable called $RestoreRequest.
trans-unit.target: Store what is returned to a variable called $RestoreRequest.

trans-unit.source: This variable contains the restore request ID which is used for monitoring the status of a restore.
trans-unit.target: This variable contains the restore request ID which is used for monitoring the status of a restore.

trans-unit.source: PS C:\>$RestoreRequest = Start-AzureSqlDatabaseRestore -SourceRestorableDroppedDatabase $Database –TargetDatabaseName “myrestoredDB”
trans-unit.target: PS C:\>$RestoreRequest = Start-AzureSqlDatabaseRestore -SourceRestorableDroppedDatabase $Database –TargetDatabaseName “myrestoredDB”

trans-unit.source: A restore may take some time to complete.
trans-unit.target: A restore may take some time to complete.

trans-unit.source: To monitor the status of the restore, use the <link><linkText>Get-AzureSqlDatabaseOperation</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet and specify the following parameters:
trans-unit.target: To monitor the status of the restore, use the <link><linkText>Get-AzureSqlDatabaseOperation</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet and specify the following parameters:

trans-unit.source: ServerName of the database you are restoring to.
trans-unit.target: ServerName of the database you are restoring to.

trans-unit.source: OperationGuid which is the Restore Request ID that was stored in the $RestoreRequest variable in Step 3.
trans-unit.target: OperationGuid which is the Restore Request ID that was stored in the $RestoreRequest variable in Step 3.

trans-unit.source: PS C:\>Get-AzureSqlDatabaseOperation –ServerName "myserver" –OperationGuid $RestoreRequest.RequestID
trans-unit.target: PS C:\>Get-AzureSqlDatabaseOperation –ServerName "myserver" –OperationGuid $RestoreRequest.RequestID

trans-unit.source: The State and PercentComplete fields show the status of the restore.
trans-unit.target: The State and PercentComplete fields show the status of the restore.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.target: For more information, see the following:

trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Azure SQL Database Business Continuity</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Azure SQL Database Backup and Restore</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>
